content.title: Vintage atmosphere and revisited cocktails at Gold Bar

introduction.small: In Seattle's South Lake Union district, Gold Bar is well-regarded, as a trendy place where to try original signature cocktails.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Vintage atmosphere and revisited cocktails at Gold Bar

paragraphs.text:
There is a place that carries its name to perfection. At Gold Bar, the bright and warm hue is very appropriate. Not without irony, this falsely bling-bling aspect insinuates everything, starting from the counter, on which funny gold-plated pineapples have been laid out. In this trendy bar, which atmosphere recalls of the industrial Seattle of the mid-20th century, colourful signature cocktails stand out against the plain black walls. Just like in a restaurant, the menu changes regularly, even though its main attraction is to reinterpret classic drinks. The Margarita becomes the Gold Bar-garita (tequila, hot pepper liquor, agave liquor and lime), the daiquiri gets a fruity twist (rum, banana liquor, lime) and the spritz is made of grapefruit-infused vodka. Served with your drinks (to be enjoyed in moderation), you will find a few snacks of Latin-American influence that Gold Bar had the wisdom to collaborate with their neighbour, Oro Kitchen, for. A perfect combination that you will best enjoy listening to a concert of local musicians.

Gold Bar
227 9th Avenue North
Seattle, WA 98109

+1 206 457 8941

www.goldbarseattle.com

Menu: cocktails from 9 USD

content.title: Vietnamese inspirations at Reckless Noodles

introduction.small: In Seattle, Reckless Noodles expresses creative cooking with a Vietnamese spirit, as well as trendy signature cocktails.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Vietnamese inspirations at Reckless Noodles

paragraphs.text:
In the historical Central District in Seattle, Reckless Noodles stands out with creative and innovative fusion food. Vietnamese gastronomy is the restaurant's main influence, also taking from Thai, Cambodian and Chinese street foods. Despite the name, noodles are not the only ingredient on the menu, even if you will notice a prominence of rice vermicelli, due to the Vietnamese linkage. In a welcoming and intimate setting complete with an overhanging fresco paying tribute to Japanese etching, you will start by selecting one of the very trendy house cocktails. Now ready, your palate will thank you for the Thit Nuóng, caramelised pork-stuffed spring roll, or the five spice duck confit, slow-cooked for 36 hours. Note that the happy hour is not limited to drinks only (to be enjoyed in moderation), so take advantage and try a few specialities to share, like the papaya salad or the roast duck crispy rolls.

Reckless Noodles
2519 South Jackson Street
Seattle, WA 98144

+1 206 329 5499

www.recklessnoodles.com

Menu: around 30 USD

content.title: Complete Change of Scenery at Westward

introduction.small: On the shores of a lake, the restaurant invites you to surrender to contemplation, while discovering quality cuisine.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Complete Change of Scenery at Westward

paragraphs.text:
Westward is located on the north shores of Lake Union, not far from the former Gas Works industrial site, which has since become a vast park. In an idyllic setting, lulled by the water lapping nearby or enshrouded with the soft light of the garlands that adorn the terrace, come and enjoy typical Pacific Northwest cuisine: octopus salad and oysters in aioli are found on a menu where fusion brings a creative touch to local products, and always in good taste. While seafood products, which change according to the day's catch, make up the majority of the dishes, a superb roasted lamb shoulder will delight the most carnivorous.
Westward occasionally organises introductory workshops on oyster preparation. Sports enthusiasts can get to the restaurant by kayak, stand-up paddle or small boat!

Westward
2501 N Northlake Way
98103 Seattle

+1 206 552 8215

www.westwardseattle.com﻿

Menu: around 40 USD

content.title: Discover the MoPOP Museum

introduction.small: The futuristic building dedicated to music, pop culture and science fiction favours interaction and new experiences.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Discover the MoPOP Museum

paragraphs.text:
Conceived and financed by Paul Allen, the famous co-founder of Microsoft, the Museum of Pop Culture (MoPOP) is devoted entirely to music. Once known as the Experimental Music Project at its opening in 2000, its primary objective was to commemorate Jimi Hendrix, a Seattle native. Since then, its scope has expanded, covering the history of rock 'n' roll and its various offshoots.
Both an exhibition space and concert hall, it currently houses a collection of 80,000 objects. Since 2004, a wing of the building accommodates the Science Fiction Museum, a tribute to another offshoot of pop culture. Artistic events and interactivity make this museum one of the most original in the United States. With learning activities at the core of its operation, you will have the opportunity to discover the secrets of music production: instruments, mixing consoles and even a studio are available to try your hand at a unique recording experience!
The MoPOP is also set apart by its masterful architecture with smooth shapes and curves, a work by the renowned Frank Gehry.

MoPOP
325 5th Avenue N
98109 Seattle

+1 206 770 2700

www.mopop.org

content.title: A perfect night out at Canon Bar

introduction.small: The star establishment of Seattle is famous in all of the United States for its rare cocktails and alcohols.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A perfect night out at Canon Bar

paragraphs.text:
Canon offers one of the most stunning spirit menus in the United States. Its owner, Jamie Boudreau, collects the rarest labels with passion. Each visit to Canon offers a new experience to try liquors or other spirits from small producers. Cocktails are not left behind where, again, the establishment has received many awards.
The decor at Canon is impressive: hundreds of bottles form a superb fresco cleverly lit in a retro-chic atmosphere. For a first visit, opt for the must-try Canon cocktail made with rye whiskey, sweet vermouth and Amaro Ramazzotti – all in moderation, of course. A gourmet menu changes seasonally, accompanied by a lovely selection of local wines.
To prolong the moment beyond your stay, purchase The Canon Cocktail Book, where Jamie Boudreau has gathered 150 of his best recipes.
The saying of the master of the house can be summarized in two words: sharing and expertise…

Canon Bar
928 12th Avenue
98122 Seattle

www.canonseattle.com

Menu: around 30 USD

content.title: Attend highly acclaimed Pacific Northwest Ballet performances

introduction.small: Considered a natural treasure, the company gives a dozen different performances per year! An experience you don't want to miss!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Attend highly acclaimed Pacific Northwest Ballet performances

paragraphs.text:
Founded in 1972, the Pacific Northwest Ballet quickly established itself as one of the best companies in North America for the rigour and quality of its ballets. It is particularly renowned for its production of pieces by George Balanchine, the Russian Ballet choreographer of Georgian origin. One production from his repertoire is included in the programme each year.
Pacific Northwest Ballet performances – for which American Peter Boal is currently the artistic director – are given at McCaw Hall, headquarters of the Seattle Opera. Nearly a dozen different stage shows are given throughout the season in this sumptuous venue, offering a full panorama of the art of dance, from the greatest classics to the most avant-garde productions.

Pacific Northwest Ballet
321 Mercer Street
98109 Seattle

+1 206 733 9725

www.pnb.org

content.title: Contemporary Art at the CoCA

introduction.small: The centre exhibits the best upcoming American and international artwork.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Contemporary Art at the CoCA

paragraphs.text:
The Center on Contemporary Art (CoCA) is a non-profit arts organisation whose mission is to display all forms of contemporary creation to the general public. From video installations to more engaging forms of militant arts, all creative scenes are represented according to many thematic exhibitions. The CoCA is also a crucial platform for emerging artists in the Seattle region and Northwestern United States.
Since its opening in 1980, the centre has successfully occupied various venues around the city. It is currently located in the Tashiro Kaplan Building, also home to many artists' studios. Tashiro Kaplan is part of a major renovation project in the Pioneer Square Historic District. The studios may be visited upon request, offering a fascinating addition to the CoCA exhibition trail.

Center on Contemporary Art
114 Third Avenue S
98104 Seattle

+1 206 728 1980

www.cocaseattle.org

content.title: Hyatt Olive 8, the environmentally-friendly student

introduction.small: The contemporary establishment is cited as an example throughout North America for its initiatives to reduce its carbon footprint.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hyatt Olive 8, the environmentally-friendly student

paragraphs.text:
In the heart of the city, the Hyatt Olive 8 is one of the most innovative hotels in terms of environmental protection. The bluish-hued building is also home to a luxury residence located on the top floors of the property, with a green roof.
Its 346 spacious and ravishingly decorated rooms make it a peaceful haven, close to the city's main shopping streets. Discover its wonderful Spa and swimming pool with a view, for a moment of optimal relaxation.
The Urbane restaurant offers the finest from local producers and farms in the area. The menu changes seasonally, favouring the inspiration of the moment.
The Hyatt Olive 8 is LEED-certified, the famous American label that ranks the best green buildings. A commendable awareness for such a prestigious establishment.

Hyatt Olive 8
1635 8th Avenue
98101 Seattle

+1 206 695 1234

https://olive8.hyatt.com

Rooms: from 220 USD

content.title: The Palladian, a stone's throw from Pike Place market

introduction.small: One of the latest in the Seattle hotel scene cultivates a chic and offbeat spirit.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Palladian, a stone's throw from Pike Place market

paragraphs.text:
The buildings were formally home to the Calhoun Hotel whose decorator, Nicole Hollis, has preserved a few historic elements such as the beautiful fireplaces. In the lobby, you are welcomed by portraits of Bill Gates and Jimi Hendrix, two of the city's many celebrities, represented as Napoleon's generals.
Among the most esteemed in Seattle, the establishment boasts a chic and offbeat, even sometimes kitschy, spirit. The rooms are spacious, each setting elaborated with vintage accents.
At Shaker + Spear, chef Carolynn Spence – from Chateau Marmont – plays the local card with an iodised cuisine: octopus, red mullet fish, subtly prepared scallops that will titillate your taste buds.
Continue your exploration with Pennyroyal, a bar renowned for its cocktails, designed as a speakeasy (in reference to the dive bars at the time of prohibition). Velvet, leather and brass create a very intimate atmosphere. More than just a hotel, the Palladian is an experience in and of itself; don't miss out on it!

Kimpton Palladian Hotel
2000 2nd Avenue
98121 Seattle

+1 206 448 1111

www.palladianhotel.com﻿

Rooms: from 160 USD

content.title: Shiro's Sushi at the height of Japanese cuisine

introduction.small: The chef boasts ancestral Tokyo traditions in the creation of his menus.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Shiro's Sushi at the height of Japanese cuisine

paragraphs.text:
The quality of the cuisine brought by Chef Shiro Kashiba since 1991 has made Shiro's Sushi one of Seattle's hottest restaurants. He has known how to bring the most of Japanese gastronomy while adopting certain customs of the region with a delicate touch.
Shiro Kashiba's secret lies in the elaboration of ancient recipes enhanced by the perfection of selected products such as hay-smoked albacore tuna, sweet onion and shiso leaf.
While the chef is now retired from the daily life of the restaurant, he has handed over supervision to Jun Takai, who carries forth the work of the master with passion. A dinner at Shiro's Sushi also allows you to discover edomae, a part of traditional Japanese cuisine, made using marinades, salting and steaming. Taste the chef's speciality, the black cod, boiled then grilled to perfection, a real treat!

Shiro's Sushi
2401 2nd Avenue
98121 Seattle

+1 206 443 9844

www.shiros.com﻿

Menu: around 80 USD

content.title: Explore the collections of Seattle Art Museum

introduction.small: From primitive art to the most contemporary works, this remarkable museum has become one of the major cultural hubs of the West Coast.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Explore the collections of Seattle Art Museum

paragraphs.text:
Better known as SAM, the Seattle Art Museum is a true cultural institution in Seattle. Established in 1933, the museum continually hosts events all year long, not hesitating to offer its many visitors themes as diverse as eclectic. It is not uncommon that a retrospective devoted to Picasso stand alongside an exhibition dedicated to the singer of Nirvana and his influence on the contemporary scene.
With over 25,000 works, the permanent collections invite you to travel across the globe – from Oceania to the first peoples of North America – and cover all the major periods of art history. Constantly supplemented by gifts from illustrious collectors, the contemporary and modern art department is not left behind. Note that, like any cultural centre of worth, the SAM offers many concerts and film screenings.

Seattle Art Museum
1300 1st Avenue
98101 Seattle

+1 206 654 3100

www.seattleartmuseum.org

content.title: W Seattle, the trendy downtown hangout

introduction.small: Design and extravagance define the character of this unique hotel, Seattle's enfant terrible.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: W Seattle, the trendy downtown hangout

paragraphs.text:
When you enter the W Seattle lounge, you will be speechless: an explosion of colours and materials dramatize a monumental fireplace. With 424 rooms and suites with contemporary decor, a fitness room and even a recording studio, the hotel is among the most renowned in the United States.
With its famous concierge service known as “Whatever/Whenever”, you are guaranteed to enjoy tailor-made service at any time of the day or night, ensuring the most perfect stay in Seattle.
Foodies will not want to miss chef Steven Ariel's creative cuisine at Trace restaurant. Here too, the show unfolds around you and in your plate. With avant-garde architecture, the restaurant offers tasty dishes made from locally produced products. Don't miss out on concerts and DJ sets that ignite the hotel's atmosphere every weekend.

W Seattle
1112 4th Avenue
98101 Seattle

+1 877 946 8357

www.whotels.com/seattle﻿

Rooms: from 300 USD

content.title: Inn at the Market, at the heart of the bustling market

introduction.small: Enjoy one of Seattle's most sought-after establishments thanks to its unique location in Pike Place.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Inn at the Market, at the heart of the bustling market

paragraphs.text:
Inn at the Market cultivates and takes on a spirit of independence, far from the standards of international chains. Ideally located, it is nestled out of sight, on the courtyard of a few shops and restaurants. The 76 rooms with a view of this boutique-hotel-style establishment have been completely renovated in a contemporary style, with warm and welcoming colours.
While the Inn at the Market does not have a restaurant on site, the team will recommend the choicest addresses in the market, all within walking distance.
Throughout the day, enjoy the terrace – the hotel's hidden treasure – facing the bay, where hot drinks and cocktails are served, as well as an excellent selection of local wines and cheeses. You will not get tired of the panoramic view, with the hectic life of the market down below.
For an even more ideal stay, choose a room overlooking the beach… A dream come true!

Inn at the Market
86 Pine Street
98101 Seattle

+1 206 443 3600

www.innatthemarket.com﻿

Rooms: from 215 USD

content.title: The rich collections of Frye Art Museum

introduction.small: Classical painting, concerts and art workshops are on the programme of this famous cultural site.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The rich collections of Frye Art Museum

paragraphs.text:
Opened in 1952, Frye Art Museum is among the most discreet art venues in Seattle and home to many masterpieces that deserve to be admired. Collections originally from the legacy of Charles and Emma Frye, a prominent couple from Seattle, have been enriched over the years through new acquisitions from private donors.
Works of American artists from the 19th and 20th centuries are displayed alongside those of German, Austrian and French painters. Paintings from symbolist Franz von Stuck – a founding member of the movement known as “The Munich Succession” – are well worth seeing. The museum also boasts a magnificent collection of old, mostly European books. In parallel, the very culturally vibrant Frye Art Museum offers various workshops open to the general public and organises various concerts and conferences. As its patrons wanted, museum entry is entirely free.

Frye Art Museum
704 Terry Avenue
98104 Seattle

+1 206 432 8206

www.fryemuseum.org

content.title: Tradition and elegance at Canlis

introduction.small: The Relais & Châteaux member restaurant is devoted to gastronomic excellence.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Tradition and elegance at Canlis

paragraphs.text:
The family establishment is one of the most reputable restaurants in Seattle: since its opening in the 50s, it has been passed on through three generations. The exquisite restaurant offers a unique view of the surrounding mountains, including the astonishing Cascade Range.
Chef Brady Williams offers contemporary cuisine where high quality dishes are in the spotlight. Menus are created daily around a main product such as beetroot or lamb, depending on the season and chef's mood.
Carefully arranged plates enhance the perfectly mastered touch in cooking.
Throughout its history, Canlis has been able to renew itself while respecting its challenge of excellence. The contemporary setting, tucked under the canopy of Aurora Avenue, will carry you away for a memorable dinner. Elegant attire is recommended to be in perfect harmony with the prestigious surroundings.

Canlis
2576 Aurora Avenue N
98109 Seattle

+1 206 283 3313

www.canlis.com﻿

Menu: around 150 USD

content.title: The Woodinville wine trail

introduction.small: Discover the region's best producers, less than half an hour from Seattle.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Woodinville wine trail

paragraphs.text:
The vineyards of Washington State are very popular among wine enthusiasts. The Woodinville area alone is worth the detour, offering the opportunity to discover the best in high-quality production and, the cherry on top, make a stop at a gastronomic restaurant.
In King County around the small city of Woodinville, which has about 10,000 inhabitants, vineyards extend as far as the eye can see. Its magnificent hilly landscape is laden with a few historical buildings, yet another reason to roam the region.
You are cordially invited to tasting tours organised by producers. Of all of the vineyards, do not miss one of its oldest, Chateau Ste. Michelle, celebrating its 50th anniversary this year. Group visits depart daily from the Woodinville Visitor Center, three kilometres south of the city; you may also choose a customised itinerary by contacting the Woodinville Visitor Center directly.

Woodinville Visitor Center
14700 148th Avenue NE
98072 Woodinville

+1 425 287 3298

www.woodinvillewinecountry.com

content.title: Dick's Drive-In's famous hamburgers

introduction.small: Generous portions and unique atmosphere for this iconic place.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Dick's Drive-In's famous hamburgers

paragraphs.text:
The very first Dick's Drive-In, which has since become a popular hamburger chain, opened its doors in 1954 in the Wallingford neighbourhood, north of Lake Union. Today there are nearly six Dick's Drive-In locations in Seattle and the surrounding area. The restaurant carries on the great American tradition of serving generous hamburgers, with giant portions of fries and XXL drinks.
Take the time to thoroughly read the ice cream and milkshake menu, a foodie's dream. Locals and visitors maintain the popularity of this place whose decor doesn't seem to have changed since the 50s. Signs with colourful typography, large cardboard menus and fluorescent neon lights evoke the great classics of American cinema. Fans won't miss a visit to the small souvenir shop to leave with a proudly stamped “Dick's” T-shirt!

Dick's Drive-In
111 NE 45th Street
98105 Seattle

+1 206 634 0300

www.ddir.com

Menu: around 15 USD

content.title: The Walrus & The Carpenter, the cool oyster bar

introduction.small: Unforgettably unique atmosphere in this establishment like no other, known for its excellent cocktails.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Walrus & The Carpenter, the cool oyster bar

paragraphs.text:
In 2010, three friends opened this small neighbourhood bistro with its terrace and zinc bar, riding the oyster bar trend.
Since then, all of Seattle packs in to enjoy the tastiest oysters in the city. The rest of the menu consists of a selection of seafood as well as a few classics such as steak tartare and Caesar salad.
Seated at the bar, face baskets of oysters exquisitely presented like at the market, while you choose from the selection of the day with the guidance of a very professional team. Order a cocktail accompanied by a platter of shellfish opened before your eyes or opt for one of the excellent wines of the region.
Brightness and warmth create a welcoming and fun atmosphere. As the restaurant does not take bookings, arriving early is advised, in order to enjoy the bartender's excellent concoctions, with funny names such as “get rich quickly”.

The Walrus & The Carpenter
4743 Ballard Avenue NW
98107 Seattle

+1 206 395 9227

www.thewalrusbar.com﻿

Menu: around 40 USD

content.title: Delve into aviation history

introduction.small: The Museum of Flight houses a very large collection of aircraft, witnesses of aeronautical advancement.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Delve into aviation history

paragraphs.text:
Seattle is the historic city of aerospace manufacturer Boeing. Opened in 1965, not far from the old warehouses of the renowned American aircraft producer, The Museum of Flight has become the largest aeronautical museum in the world. During your visit, you will discover an old Concorde that belonged to British Airways, a version of the Boeing 747 – the famous double-decker aircraft, as well as the first presidential jet to bear the Air Force One name.
Older aircraft are exhibited in hangars, such as the famous DC3, in addition to specimens of military aircraft and very recent models like the 787 Dreamliner, the latest addition to the Boeing commercial line which recently found its place at the Museum of Flight. Space adventure is not forgotten, with a hangar specifically dedicated to Apollo flights. The most daring will appreciate the experience of testing flight simulators or immersing themselves in the unique setting of a control tower.

The Museum of Flight
9404 E. Marginal Way South
98108 Seattle

+1 206 764 5700

www.museumofflight.org

content.title: Chinatown and memories of Bruce Lee

introduction.small: The neighbourhood allows you to discover all the Asian cultures that shaped the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Chinatown and memories of Bruce Lee

paragraphs.text:
Rich with numerous foreign communities, Seattle is home to a large Asian population. As in all major American cities, a neighbourhood named Chinatown has flourished since the beginning of the city's recent history. This highly touristy neighbourhood, especially during Chinese New Year celebrations, is also famous for its gastronomic addresses, from the most traditional to the newest trendy fusion restaurants.
The young Bruce Lee was educated in Seattle's Chinatown, far from the Chinese gangs in San Francisco that his mother wanted to move away from. The Wing Luke Museum organizes excursions in the footsteps of the legendary actor specialized in Kung Fu films. Tour guides will show you his favourite places, including restaurants and one of his training rooms. The visit continues with the discovery of the Wing Luke Museum, whose collections pay homage to all aspects of Asian culture.

Wing Luke Museum
719 South King Street
98104 Seattle

+1 206 623 5124

www.wingluke.org

content.title: Lark, contemporary American inspiration

introduction.small: Chef John Sundstrom prepares seasonal cuisine in a splendid establishment.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Lark, contemporary American inspiration

paragraphs.text:
For over 15 years, John Sundstrom has tirelessly devoted himself to a very personal approach to cooking. His menus borrow from all cuisines, with distilled tributes to the Japanese savoir-faire as well as to the French terroir – for example, his Robuchon potatoes.
The chef makes a point of honour to highlight all of his suppliers, by listing his restaurant's partner farms on his website. Here, seafood and shellfish from the sound, Wagyu beef cuts and homemade foie gras all border on excellence.
On two floors, the restaurant's setting will dazzle you with its light wood ceilings embellished with a multitude of small bulbs and large unfinished wood tables.
In front of Lark, the chef has opened a more affordable restaurant dedicated to sandwiches and salads, where quality will meet your expectations: beyond reproach.

Lark
952 E Seneca Street
98122 Seattle

+1 206 323 5275

www.larkseattle.com/﻿

Menu: around 80 USD

content.title: Joule, a journey to Korea

introduction.small: One of the best restaurants in Seattle to rediscover steakhouse traditions.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Joule, a journey to Korea

paragraphs.text:
Chefs Rachel Yang and Seif Chirchi, trained by Alain Ducasse, among others, have combined their talents for the past 10 years in their alluring establishment.
The interior décor opts for a sober and contemporary design, with a sense of all-Asian purity.
Recently, a new concept is revisiting the principles of a Korean version steakhouse. The refinement of the creations transcends the taste of the meat, such as the smokehouse steak with a Vietnamese coffee rub and parsnip. The varied menu offers mouthwatering starters: the yellow curry pickled beet, fig and olive, with spiced pistachio oil is a must-try! Joule also offers light dinner options, which can be shared around the table, ideal for a little snack before the show.
The restaurant is only open in the evening, with a weekend brunch served from 10:00 a.m. to 2:00 p.m.

Joule
3506 Stone Way N
98103 Seattle

+1 206 632 5685

www.relayrestaurantgroup.com/restaurants/joule/﻿

Menu: around 45 USD

content.title: Learn about modern and emerging Native American Art

introduction.small: The Steinbrueck Native Gallery displays beautifully arranged rare works.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Learn about modern and emerging Native American Art

paragraphs.text:
The gallery pays tribute to Seattle's distant Indian past. Far from “ancient” art collections usually displayed in more traditional museums in the city, it mainly exhibits modern and contemporary Native American works. There you will discover not only the most recent work of many Native American peoples of Washington State, but also of western Canada. Do not hesitate to ask their passionate employees any questions, as they will be delighted to enrich your visit.
In the midst of the various treasures displayed, your eyes will move quickly from an array of modern art – with its bright and colourful hues – to some of the wonders of craft and weaving, not to mention the splendid collections of masks and jewellery. With permanent exhibitions and various occasional events, Steinbrueck does incredible educational work for Native American culture.

Steinbrueck Native Gallery
2030 Western Avenue
98121 Seattle

+1 206 441 3821

www.steinbruecknativegallery.com

content.title: Take a stroll in the Olympic Sculpture Park

introduction.small: The greatest American sculptors display masterful works in the magnificent gardens by the water.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Take a stroll in the Olympic Sculpture Park

paragraphs.text:
Dependent on the Seattle Art Museum, this former industrial wasteland has become a prominent open-air museum and offers visitors a lovely promenade with walkways spreading over more than 36,000 square metres. Architects from Weiss/Manfredi have conceived a splendid path, inviting you to discover the many monumental sculptures scattered all around.
Wander among the greatest masterpieces of their kind; tours are completely free. Among others, don't miss Alexandre Calder's famous Eagle or the creations of Louise Bourgeois, Jaume Plensa or Mark di Suvero. Known for his spectacular steel statues, Richard Serra is also present with his gigantic Wake sculpture, composed of five elements. The park is open daily, in all seasons.

Olympic Sculpture Park
2901 Western Avenue
98121 Seattle

+1 206 654 3100

www.seattleartmuseum.org/visit/olympic-sculpture-park

content.title: Visit the Seattle Aquarium with Little Ones

introduction.small: Entertaining and scientific journey into the heart of the Pacific's marine life.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Visit the Seattle Aquarium with Little Ones

paragraphs.text:
Located on the seafront, the Seattle Aquarium is devoted to the conservation of fish and marine mammals. Since its opening over 40 years ago, the oceanographic park is continually upgrading their facilities. The path is very well thought-out, between the various tanks and discovery areas. Many local species of underwater fauna, such as salmon, sea anemones and a variety of scorpion fish from the North Pacific were introduced in one of the largest aquariums, containing nearly 550,000 litres of water.
The aquarium carries on a two-fold mission: protecting the most threatened species and educating the general public. For this purpose, divers enter the tanks several times a day to answer a myriad of visitors' questions. The Seattle Aquarium is also involved in several initiatives to come to the rescue of sea turtles as well as coral, which is strongly impacted by the effects of global warming.

Seattle Aquarium
1483 Alaskan Way, Pier 59
98101 Seattle

+1 206 386 4300

www.seattleaquarium.org

content.title: Stopover at one of the best organic chocolate shops in the city

introduction.small: Theo Chocolate reveals all of its preparation secrets and takes you away to its creative foodie workshop for even more magic!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Stopover at one of the best organic chocolate shops in the city

paragraphs.text:
Welcome to the first all-organic chocolate factory in the United States. Located in the Fremont neighbourhood, this old red brick factory is home to a wonderful local initiative. The owners have chosen to produce chocolate exclusively from organic farming, by selecting fair trade beans and monitoring the carbon footprint of the manufacturing process.
To find the factory, it couldn't be simpler: let yourself be guided by the delicious scent. Once inside the building, you will begin a one-hour tour with an introduction to the process of creating chocolate, while enjoying a variety of flavours. Raspberry, ginger, caramel… There is something for everyone's taste! Continue your epic journey through the impressive machine room before moving into the confection kitchen, where flavours are blended. For the biggest chocolate lovers, don't hesitate to wander around the shop and bring back some souvenirs!

Theo Chocolate
3400 Phinney Avenue N
98103 Seattle

+1 206 632 5100

www.theochocolate.com

content.title: Max, when pop music and modern art take over the hotel

introduction.small: An original establishment that cultivates a spirit of its own in the city's rock tradition.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Max, when pop music and modern art take over the hotel

paragraphs.text:
There, you will find art around every corner. From the lobby to the doors of the rooms, the Max shelters over 350 works, a real little museum!
Admire paintings from local artists on the walls, alongside the giants of modern art such as Andy Warhol (with one of his famous Campbell's Soup pieces) and Ed Ruscha.
Relax in your room, with contemporary and refined décor, for a sensational immersion in the warm pop universe of this atypical establishment.
Just nearby, at 620 Stewart Street, discover Sub Pop, a music label created in Seattle in 1986. A complimentary compilation will be given to you at the end of your stay.
Finish your journey with Miller's Guide and its enormous grill: mature beef, fresh fish and seafood from the coast sizzle before your hungry eyes. Welcome to the Max!

Hotel Max
612 Stewart Street
98101 Seattle

+1 206 728 6299

www.hotelmaxseattle.com﻿

Rooms: from 120 USD

content.title: In dinosaur footprints at Burke Museum

introduction.small: Little ones love to explore the astonishing collections from this historic place that holds many surprises.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: In dinosaur footprints at Burke Museum

paragraphs.text:
Established in 1899, the Burke Museum is one of the oldest natural history museums in the United States. Expect to see real treasures by perusing the fascinating departments dedicated to palaeontology, as well as botany.
The Seattle region was a rich field of discovery in all areas of life and Earth sciences, allowing the Burke Museum to gather one of the finest collections of fossils in the United States. In particular, don't miss the famous T. Rex skull, discovered by a Burke Museum team in 2016.
Numerous children's activities are offered throughout the year, particularly to reveal the behind-the-scenes work of palaeontologists. During the summer, entire days are even dedicated to toddlers with themed workshops. And guess which are the most popular? Those about dinosaurs, of course!

Burke Museum
1413 NE 45th Street
98105 Seattle

+1 206 543 7907

www.burkemuseum.org

content.title: Visit Rem Koolhaas' library

introduction.small: This major architectural work has helped to revitalize the city centre.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Visit Rem Koolhaas' library

paragraphs.text:
In just a few years, the Seattle Public Library has become one of the city's strong symbols. Inaugurated in 2004, this splendid glass and steel building is the work of Dutch architect Rem Koolhaas, who also designed the Casa da Música in Porto and the China Central Television headquarters in Beijing. While the exterior is reminiscent of a contemporary art sculpture, the interior appears to pay tribute to the Egyptian pyramids: a maze of galleries lined with bookshelves (with over a million books available) leads visitors to the reading rooms flooded with light emerging from the monumental glass roof.
Partially financed by Bill Gates, the library – whose building meets the city's strict environmental standards – does not require any prior registration. Up to you to freely enjoy its wealth. Since its opening, the Public Library has been a huge success and its visitor rate remains strong. It must be said that Seattle is considered to be one of the most literary cities in the United States.

Seattle Public Library
1000 4th Avenue
98104 Seattle

+1 206 386 4636

www.spl.org/locations/central-library

content.title: Ace Seattle, the bohemian chic spirit

introduction.small: The very trendy establishment goes against the rules of traditional hotels.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Ace Seattle, the bohemian chic spirit

paragraphs.text:
Since its establishment in 1999, in the hip Belltown neighbourhood, within the walls of a former maritime workers' hotel, the Ace Seattle sets the bar for cool and trendy hotels.
The spot evokes an industrial loft feel warmed by its unfinished hardwood floors, a subtle alliance between selective design and unpretentious luxury that will immediately make you feel right at home!
In the rooms, white brick walls exhibit works by famous artists (like KAWS and Shepard Fairey), where you will also find contemporary designer furniture alongside vintage and recycled items. The Ace Seattle demonstrates its uniqueness in even offering common bathrooms out of respect for the environment, allowing its customers to spend less time under the shower!
The hotel does not have a restaurant, but serves delicious coffee from a Portland roaster in an open kitchen in the breakfast room. It's the small things that make all the difference…

Ace Seattle
2423 1st Avenue
98121 Seattle

+1 206 448 4721

www.acehotel.com/seattle﻿

Rooms: from 120 USD

content.title: Kimpton Alexis, a sense of hospitality

introduction.small: The hotel plays the classic card in its decoration, while offering first-rate new technology to its customers.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Kimpton Alexis, a sense of hospitality

paragraphs.text:
The Kimpton Alexis occupies three old buildings in the West Edge neighbourhood, dating back to 1901 and listed on the National Register of Historic Places. The hotel stands out with its high ceilings and vast common areas, reminiscent of large American homes.
The rooms and suites celebrate the marriage of tradition and modernity, where connected speakers developed by Amazon – the American giant born in Seattle – are juxtaposed with brick walls, thick carpets and fireplaces.
The hotel's restaurant, The Bookstore, has a quirky vibe. Surrounded by shelves of books, you will have the pleasant feeling of being in an old living room. At any time, day or night, you can have a snack or savour dishes prepared from local products over candlelight. The Kimpton Alexis, or the quintessence of elegance and simplicity.

Kimpton Alexis
1007 1st Avenue
98104 Seattle

+1 206 624 4844

www.alexishotel.com﻿

Rooms: from 190 USD

content.title: From the top of the Space Needle

introduction.small: The 184-metre observation tower overlooks Seattle and the surrounding areas.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: From the top of the Space Needle

paragraphs.text:
Since its opening in 1962, the Space Needle has been one of the most popular attractions in Seattle. The work of two very inventive architects, Edward E. Carlson and John Graham Jr., the tower is not only a reference to space exploration, but one particularly to the science-fiction narratives of the time. Moreover, the top of the Space Needle appears to be mistaken for a flying saucer such as those popularised by movies like Robert Wise's The Day the Earth Stood Still.
From the top of the architecturally futuristic tower, a spectacular panorama awaits you. Well beyond Seattle, the view reaches the beautiful mountain ranges surrounding both sides of the city. SkyCity, its famous restaurant perched on a rotating circular plateau, has been under renovation since 2017; its reopening is anticipated by all. Suspended at nearly 180 metres high, there is no question that its glass floor will become an absolute must for those who love heights and seek thrills. Accessible by elevator, the observation deck is open daily from 10:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m. and from 9:00 a.m. to 9:00 p.m. on Fridays and Saturdays.

Space Needle
400 Broad Street
98109 Seattle

+1 206 905 2100

www.spaceneedle.com

content.title: Thompson, bold contemporary architecture

introduction.small: The popular rooftop hotel is among the city's most elegant addresses, just steps away from the famous Pike Place market.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Thompson, bold contemporary architecture

paragraphs.text:
Architects Jim Olson and Tom Kundig designed the impressive glass building with futuristic and elegant lines. Thompson is among the city's newest establishments, as seen by its exquisite rooms all adorned with oversized windows. The sunlight pours in, magnifying the light wood floors and 50s-inspired furniture. Juxtaposed with references to the world of aviation, the decor meets the tapered and airy architecture of the hotel.
Do you fancy a gourmet break or discovery dinner? The Scout welcomes you in its midst, replete with blond pine decor and coppery accents. Its menu sheds a light on local products: wild mushrooms from the mountains, shellfish from the Puget Sound… On the rooftop terrace, the already famous The Nest bar awaits you: on a clear day, enjoy stunning views of the surrounding mountains while sipping on the best cocktails of the moment.

Thompson Seattle
110 Stewart Street
98101 Seattle

+1 206 623 4600

www.thompsonhotels.com/hotels/seattle/thompson-seattle﻿

Rooms: from 170 USD

content.title: Visit the heart of the Amazon Spheres

introduction.small: Once again, the American giant distinguishes itself with this hybrid site, between a botanical garden and a workspace.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Visit the heart of the Amazon Spheres

paragraphs.text:
The Amazon Spheres opened at the beginning of 2018, in the heart of Seattle's city centre. Designed by NBBJ architects, these three giant biospheres house over 40,000 plants, from 400 different species selected from all over the world. Among the many attractions, discover a magnificent Port Jackson fig tree that stands over 17 metres high.
While Amazon's new official headquarters – with a stock market value of over $500 billion – is, above all, an incredible workplace dedicated to its employees, visitors are also welcome. An exhibition space, as well as a gastronomic restaurant, were even created for them. Amazon also organizes company tours in small groups. They are free, but do not forget to register well in advance, online only, as it's been an incredibly popular spot since its opening.

Amazon Spheres
2101 7th Avenue
98119 Seattle

www.seattlespheres.com

content.title: Loews 1000, rooms with a bird's eye view of the Pacific Ocean

introduction.small: Refinement and sophistication distinguish this hotel which wins all the votes.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Loews 1000, rooms with a bird's eye view of the Pacific Ocean

paragraphs.text:
The small tower overlooks Seattle Bay. Loews Hotel 1000, completely renovated after being purchased by the Loews Group, offers a haven of luxury. Suites with seafront views are among the most gorgeous in the city.
Enjoy its spacious rooms in beige powder tones and elegant Spa for a moment of relaxation.
Delight your taste buds at All Water Seafood, run by Chef Scott Mickelson, whose menu pays tribute to nearby seafood products, or reserve a table at the Oyster – the excellent oyster bar that is packed on the weekends.
Located just steps away from the art gallery neighbourhood, not far from all of the city's major attractions, the hotel – considered one of the nicest on the West Coast – continues to earn more and more awards in the United States. Hurry!

Loews Hotel 1000
1000 1st Avenue
98104 Seattle

+1 206 957 1000

www.loewshotels.com/hotel-1000-seattle﻿

Rooms: from 310 USD

content.title: Behind the scenes at Boeing

introduction.small: The aviation giant is building part of its fleet in Seattle, where an exhibition centre welcomes visitors passionate about air transport.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Behind the scenes at Boeing

paragraphs.text:
While the head office of Boeing is located in Chicago, Illinois, one of the company's two largest factories is located about 40 kilometres north of Seattle. After a short introductory video, your tour will begin with a walk through some of the 3.7 kilometres of tunnels, under the gigantic factory. Once inside the largest building in the world, known as the Boeing Everett Factory, you will discover the assembly methods of the wings, tail and engines of the Boeing 747, 767, 777 and even 787, also known as the Dreamliner.
An interactive workshop provides you with the opportunity to play aeronautical engineers by “virtually” designing your own aircraft. The tour also includes exhibitions on commercial aviation and a detour through the immense panoramic terrace. From there, you will see the runways of the nearby Paine Field Airport, where Boeings constantly take off and land.

Future of Flight Aviation Center & Boeing Tour
8415 Paine Field Boulevard
98275 Mukilteo

+1 800 464 1476

www.futureofflight.org

content.title: Delancey, the art of an excellent pizza

introduction.small: This charming restaurant is one of the hottest spots in the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Delancey, the art of an excellent pizza

paragraphs.text:
The entire city followed the adventures of the opening of this pizzeria, told in a novel written by Molly Wizenberg, the co-owner of the restaurant. She particularly describes the demanding nature of Petitt, her partner, driven by the fierce desire to make the most wonderful pizzas and his anxiety in creating recipes.
The reception of the public and critics was not long in coming. Everyone agrees that Delancey produces the best pizzas in the area – an undisputed success with their crispy and airy crust cooked to perfection in a wood-fired oven, and the freshest ingredients. As for the choice of tomatoes and mozzarella, they are meticulous with the finest suppliers.
In a cheerful, bright and relaxed atmosphere, come and taste the famous pizzas that have resisted the marriage of Molly and Pettit. A happy ending that does not only exist in movies!

Delancey
1415 NW 70th Street
98117 Seattle

+1 206 838 1960

www.delanceyseattle.com/﻿

Menu: around 25 USD

content.title: Hiking and cross-country skiing at Mount Rainier

introduction.small: Discover the most famous volcano of the Northwest, between glaciers and magnificent forests.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hiking and cross-country skiing at Mount Rainier

paragraphs.text:
In the heart of the Cascade Mountains, at an altitude of 4,392 metres, is Mount Rainier, a “stratovolcano”, meaning its structure consists of an accumulation of successive lava flows. Whether you are a great athlete or simply a wilderness lover, Mount Rainier offers a wide range of activities. The most adventurous can even climb the summit, under the supervision of an experienced mountaineer. It must be said that, amidst the permanent snow, the view is simply breathtaking.
Without climbing so high, it is possible, in winter, to go cross-country skiing or for an unforgettable hike in snow shoes. On sunny days, Mount Rainier attracts visitors from all over the world who enjoy camping, hiking and cycling. As the wildlife is very well-protected, information centres are available at the various park entrances to explain the rules of conduct and precautions to take, especially around brown bears who do not like to be bothered. Perhaps you will have the chance to see one from afar!

www.nps.gov/mora/index.htm

content.title: Four Seasons, the excellence of a small palace with a view

introduction.small: The prestigious Canadian chain offers a luxurious contemporary retreat in the heart of the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Four Seasons, the excellence of a small palace with a view

paragraphs.text:
The very modern establishment towers over Elliott Bay with a view overlooking the ocean and the Olympic mountain range that surrounds Seattle.
Large windows in the rooms and suites, dressed in beige tones with Asian influences, provide a fascinating show of the coming and goings of boats leaving the port.
In the lobby, the Goldfinch Tavern restaurant welcomes you to savour a platter of oysters or taste its innovative cuisine focused on seafood and other local products.
Treat yourself to a moment of relaxation at the Spa, made of all raw materials, or enjoy one of the exclusive tours offered by the hotel, such as a meeting with the artist Dale Chihuly, the famous Native American artist who does glasswork.
Finally, climb up to the rooftop terrace. Have a seat in a comfortable armchair around a coffee table near the splendid infinity pool, where the fire will warm the evening air, and enjoy a drink facing the horizon.

Four Seasons
99 Union Street
98101 Seattle

+1 206 239 1814

www.fourseasons.com/seattle

Rooms: from 500 USD

content.title: The chic saloon of Bathtub Gin & Co

introduction.small: The discreet establishment cultivates the image of a prohibition style cocktail bar.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The chic saloon of Bathtub Gin & Co

paragraphs.text:
The bar is among the addresses that only insiders know. Its small size is not conducive to large parties, but rather calm discussions around an excellent cocktail. Bathtub Gin & Co, also very popular for its generous happy hour, is located in the basement of an old brick hotel, now a chic residence. Travel through time when entering this speakeasy-inspired location (illicit establishments known only by insiders at the time of Al Capone).
The decoration has a retro feel, from antique furniture to vintage photos, where Bathtub revisits the atmosphere of the 1920s. As for cocktails, the short menu offers excellent rums, a nice variety of tequilas, and – not to forget – the specialty of the house, gins. The bar offers about 30 varieties including ones from small producers from the State of Washington and nearby Oregon (to drink in moderation). As the establishment can only accommodate about 40 customers, try to arrive early to enjoy this place like no other!

Bathtub Gin & Co
2205 Second Avenue
98121 Seattle

+1 206 728 6069

www.bathtubginseattle.com

Cocktail: around 12 USD

content.title: Discover the wealth of Pike Place Market

introduction.small: In a unique setting, the organic market offers the nicest products from the states of Washington and Oregon.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Discover the wealth of Pike Place Market

paragraphs.text:
Pike Place Market has become a leading tourist attraction in Seattle. Its operation has remained traditional for over a century. You should therefore not hesitate to discover the immense variety of products offered. There, local farms sell their best cheeses and a wide range of high-quality fruits and vegetables, while fishmongers, who like to challenge themselves, put on a show by flying their biggest fish from one stand to another.
Opened in 1907, this immense public market remains an exception in the United States today, where very few similar places remain in the centres of large cities. Pike Place almost disappeared to make room for… a car park. Faced with the residents' discontentment, its demolition was soon cancelled in favour of large-scale modernisation.
Paradoxically, this is where the famous Starbucks Group was born in 1971! You can visit the first store of the brand that's now global. Of very modest size, it offered the best coffee on the market at the time, made according to traditional production methods.

Pike Place Market
85 Pike Street
98101 Seattle

+1 206 682 7453

www.pikeplacemarket.org

content.title: Seattle or the art of glass

introduction.small: Discover Chihuly Garden and Glass and dive into an enchanting world to find impressive multi-coloured sculptures.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Seattle or the art of glass

paragraphs.text:
Nestled in the middle of the Seattle Center, just a few steps away from the MoPOP and Space Needle, Chihuly Garden and Glass exhibits the remarkable works of Dale Chihuly, considered one of the greatest Native American artists in the country. There you will discover his incredible glasswork, which he learned to blow like a “fire genie”.
During your visit, you will be able to admire the countless objects and sculptures in three different spaces. First, the galleries will introduce you to the artist's fairy tale world while drawing on his experiences and inspirations. The glasshouse will dazzle you with its expansive 30-metre-long installation of colourful flowers. The outdoor garden will then captivate you with its harmonious juxtaposition of both real and glass plants. You will be consumed by the magic of this amazing place before being guided by the various staging and lighting effects. Don't miss out on this remarkable place, as glass is one of Seattle's most unexpected specialties!

Chihuly Garden and Glass
305 Harrison Street
98109 Seattle

+1 206 905 2180

www.chihulygardenandglass.com/

content.title: Olympic National Park

introduction.small: Olympic National Park covers over 3,734 sqm, where all nature and hiking enthusiasts can have a great time.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Olympic National Park

paragraphs.text:
West of Seattle, this vast peninsula with heart-stopping scenery has become a paradise for those who love walking. To take advantage of this magical place, you have to drive or take a ferry there. From the small town of Port Angeles, where ships load and unload tree trunks at sunrise, you will reach Olympic National Park through the northern entrance: Hurricane Ridge.
There, in the hollow of the green valleys, stretches the largest area of virgin forest in all of the United States – some thousand-year-old trees measure up to 91 metres tall! Be sure to take a detour to Crescent Lake, formed nearly 7,000 years ago, reaching depths of 200 metres in some places! Alternately, explore the heart of the Hoh Rain Forest, the largest temperate rain forest in the world. In the park, all trails are perfectly marked, where you will have plenty of time to play explorer and reconnect with nature.

Olympic National Park Visitor Center
3002 Mount Angeles Road
98362 Port Angeles

+1 360 565 3130

www.nps.gov/olym/index.htm
